title: Divorce - Case Status Conference - What should I expect?
question: I have a case status conference coming up in a couple of weeks. I am curious as to what I should prepare for the conference? Any ideas on what the judge might be looking for? I would like to be prepared.
question_tags: Divorce,Dividing debts in a divorce,Alimony,Divorce and bankruptcy,Child custody,Family court and child custody cases,Bankruptcy,Debt,Nondischargeable debt and alimony,Bankruptcy and debt,Divorce and family,Real estate and bankruptcy,Property tax value,Real estate,Family law
answers: the purpose is to make sure the preliminary declaration of disclosure has been filed and if you are ready for trial. that is to say all discovery has been completed, what are the issues in dispute property, values of property, debts, credits being claimed, child custody disputed, in essence why can't the case be resolved ? be able to tell the court the issues, time it will take, number of exhibits and number of witnesses. If there are several issues get counsel don't to this on your own.

The judge probably won't even call the case. You need not prepare. If you spouse is not complying with discovery demands, then you need to compel further/more complete responses by filing a motion to compel. That is somewhat tricky and having counsel might be helpful. In addition, you have a limited period of time during which to file a motion to compel--which may have already passed. If you would like to skip attending the status conference, you can file a status report, which is a local form which may be found by searching for "VN126." It sounds like you want to move this thing forward, so it may be helpful for you to cause a mandatory settlement conference by filing a request for one.
Best of luck.
And, as to the issues of non-disclosure, those should be put in writing in a comprehensive letter to the other side. Hire a lawyer to help you.

Status conference is to determine whether the case is moving forward. Divorce cases can take a long time depending on a variety of different issues. I suggest you seek an attorney to represent your interest if your divorce contains marital or separate property assets, children, or the possibility of spousal support.
